text: Hello, welcome back.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We're here with real Bradley Lycia and recorded Stefan Bohlmann.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There will be a pre-recorded talk with some discussion too.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So thanks all and looking forward to the talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Go for it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Is this coming through?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Yes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay, wonderful.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well then, yeah, welcome everyone to my presentation about NeuroDesk.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: My name is Jeffen Bollmann.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I'm a senior research fellow at University of Queensland in Australia.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And sorry, I can't be there live, but the time zones are just too difficult.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I want to start with why we built NeuroDesk and then introduce what it is.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But we saw a couple of challenges in open science.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And one of them is really non-reproducible workflows.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have different great tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They run on lots of different data sets.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But the challenge is that if underlying dependencies change, they produce slightly different results.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really not great if we want to infer anything on this data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The other challenge that we saw is infrastructure disparities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So lots of people have access to different computer resources.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So be it their own notebook, the HPC cluster, or their cloud provider to process their data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And wherever they want to run data analysis, they need to come and install their software again.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the software will be different across these installations and often costs a lot of time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, it produces different results, but also costs a lot of time in maintaining these different installations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: other challenge that we see is data management so when you acquire experimental data then from an mri scanner for example or behavioral data then we have to organize in some sense and a lot of different tools but we wanted to see if we could make that a lot easier and then also data storage and privacy so where we store this data how we collaborate with others how can we make this data
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: openly available to others these are really questions that we had and thought well can we somehow make this nice and nicer for people and easier to use so why is it so difficult um in the end all the software that i use for neuroimaging analyses are are software pieces that depend on other software pieces and these we often call libraries and what they do is these libraries provide
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: functionality that you don't want to re-implement.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For example, you have your software here that does some brain imaging analysis, and then you don't want to reinvent how windows are drawn on a computer or how data is plotted or how images are processed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you want to use what other people have already built to do these functionalities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then what happens is your software starts depending on these because you're using functionality from these.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: this usually works quite well and the reason is that we have in linux for example with package managers like apt yum or if you use python for your work we have conda and pip but pretty much all languages systems have some kind of package management system that keep dependencies compatible with each other and that's really how it looks like it's like a puzzle piece where if one thing upgrades another thing has to upgrade as well they have to have matching versions and then we're hoping that this all works
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The challenge is with a lot of the scientific software that we work with, it's often built by scientists who don't have a lot of time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They're not really software engineers a lot of the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what happens is they have unpackaged scientific software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So these
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: scientific software packages are not available in standard package systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that means that if the operating system upgrades, the package manager doesn't know about this software because it's not registered there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then what happens is the package manager changes something.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And because it didn't know about the software, then it breaks.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: happens, unfortunately, quite often with scientific software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it leads to two problems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, here's our reproducibility problem, because if we're just dependent on a library and even if it doesn't break, let's say it just changes functionality, our results will be different.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really bad for reproducibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And also, this means portability, because if our software is tightly integrated with the system, it means we can't install software on our notebook and then run exactly the same software on a high-performance computing system, because that will have slightly different dependencies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we need to install it again, often compile it from source code, which can be really a lot of work.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to show this reproducibility problem in a little bit more detail, this is a great article that looked at software that depends on glibc.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: glibc is a very fundamental Linux library.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what they did is they varied only that library version
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: um and they left the main piece of the software intact so they used free server and lots of other pieces but i'll focus here on free server um so it's the same software installation just a different operating system just in different linux versions in the end
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and what happened is in glibc the exponential function for example was altered and was made more efficient but unfortunately this meant that the precision of this function changed so now you would think that this doesn't matter right it's like very uh a couple digits after um uh so yeah so it should be quite insignificant unfortunately it's not because free suffer in particular has a it's a long running pipeline where we segment the human brain
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and this means that if you have small changes this accumulates over thousands of processing steps so this means in the end here they found differences in millimeter up to 0.2 millimeter in the cortex where
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a change that's only based on a software version of this underlying glibc.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So FreeSoft was identical.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The only thing that changed was the operating system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the thing is, this was even statistically significant in some areas.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really not what we want, because if you acquire patient data on one software version and then you have matched controls on another software version, then that would really lead to significant results that are actually meaningless because they're just based on computational noise.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the organic solution that I've seen in my career is that we just have people set up different computers and don't touch them, don't try to update them because people are aware of these problems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and this is not great because it's not a great use of resources and also it means we can't easily take our software and run it in different computers and this is this portability problem where let's say you want to run the same software on your notebook on your lab workstation in a secure environment on a cloud provider on a high performance computing cluster or even on the instrument where you're acquiring your data like your MRIs you can't just easily build an algorithm on your notebook and then run it on the MRI scanner it's currently not possible
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But that would be cool, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For translational studies in patients, it would be fantastic if you had a model that you build on your notebook, you validate it on lots of data, and then you can actually deploy it in real clinical environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That would be fantastic.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is really the problems that we're trying to solve with this project.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we adopted one solution for this, which is called software containers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I quickly want to introduce what software containers are and how they work, because our software is based on all of this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So software containers, if you've never heard of them, a very simple thought pattern is they're just boxes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They're boxes to put software in.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I really like the stuff where you put food in and put it in your fridge.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's fantastic because it keeps things separated and you can move them easily.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They're very portable and they don't depend on each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really what software containers do.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They use specific Linux kernel features called namespaces and cgroups.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They isolate processes and dependencies from each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this means we can put everything our software needs into a standardized box and we can move that across operating systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what it basically changes from our mental model when I said earlier, we have this Lego piece where this piece depends tightly on the other things in the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This now changes to where we take these dependencies, we put them into the same box.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So now we actually don't have dependency on the system anymore.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The box got a bit bigger because we have these dependencies not included.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But in the end, storage is cheap.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: but experiments scientific experiments are expensive so this is a very low price to pay for a lot of great features and the whole cloud world everything the internet depends on today is based on software containers so this is really a very mature standard that has been adopted everywhere in the computing industry so in science we're just we should just do it as well um
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we can do, we can package all of our software in these boxes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then because we have these standardized interfaces now, we can run this on Windows, Linux, and Mac.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: On Linux, this is a standard kernel feature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So no performance penalties, very easy to run.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: On Mac and Linux, we have some virtualization technology that we need, but that got really good over the last years.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you will not feel that it's slow.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It still feels very native, but there is some virtualization, there is some overhead, but it's tiny compared to what we had a couple of years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: so then let's come to what we built um before i show what we've built in your desk is i want to acknowledge all the people working on this project because yes i'm giving a talk here today but i'm just one of many contributors um we started this project really during covert because we are all bored and sitting at home and we said well let's let's solve that problem why not right we have time um so we got together a couple people uh all highlighted in in
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: in bold here and said, okay, let's build this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We built a prototype during a hackathon at the OHPM and we got funding from the AIDC to build a bigger version of this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then, yeah, we got lots of people involved.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Slide change, sorry.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We got lots of people involved from across the world and lots more supporters like the big cloud providers, AWS.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Google had supported us in the past as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then also the
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the university cloud providers like EGI, Jetstream, AIDC, Nectar Cloud.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that helps a lot.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And yeah, we're currently funded by the Mark & Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and the Wellcome Trust to build that system out further over the next years.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is what we built.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I'll start here at the container level.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is really the software containers that I introduced earlier, where we build a software container for every piece of software that people want in this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here we have a couple of neuroimaging pieces, so fMRI prep, FreeSurfer, FieldTrip, ENTS, and then we can control everything in there from the binaries, the libraries that we have in there, up to the actual software that people want in the end, like M&E, which then depends on Python, which then depends on Conva, and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can control all of these dependencies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then if you've used the software container before, they are fantastic, but they're not always easy to use.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Like you have to run specific commands like Docker run, or if you're on an HPC, you need to run Singularity or AppTainer run.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we didn't want that people have to think about this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we build an accessibility layer, we call it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But in the end, it's just an abstraction across multiple container technologies that we use.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and it's also a way how we can stream containers to end users so people don't have to download these containers so this this little block here was actually the most of the work that we spend on how do we get these containers to end users and how do we make it easy for people to use that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But ultimately, what this allows us now to do is we can run these containers on any system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can run this on Mac OS, on Linux, on the cloud, on Windows, on high performance computing clusters, in Jupyter notebooks like Google Colab, on the terminal.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: pretty much anywhere and we try to indicate this here with this little script that goes between systems and that's not the thing that wasn't possible before we can code up an analysis on our notebook and we can move it across all these systems and will perform identically and behave identically across all of these systems so this really is fantastic for collaboration for translation of results and for reproducibility in general
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the community uses that interacts with the system, but also finds problems, bugs, and then reports back and contributes new containers, new things that people want to use in the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really the ecosystem that we've built.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the best way to get started with NeuroDesk is go to our website, neurodesk.org, where you find two very quick ways to get started.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you want to run a hosted version of this, which runs on the cloud, or if you want to run a local version, which runs on your computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it depends on your use case.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you have data, patient data, you definitely want to run this locally.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you have open data, you can use a hosted version and you're fine.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we have a more fine grained table down here where you can select what your compute platform is, what your operating system is, what the interface is that you use.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then you get guided to the documentation where we guide you through how to run this on your system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: in the end what you're getting is you're getting a virtual desktop which is just a linux desktop with all the tools installed and the cool thing is all the software is ready to go so you don't need to install anything everything is there we have no dependency issues so we can even have
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the same software in different versions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So, for example, FreeSurfer is almost impossible to install different versions of that software on your computer because it will replace dependencies that other pieces depend on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But because we wrap all these dependencies in a software container, we can actually provide all versions of FreeSurfer, for example, going back over the last years without any problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: because of this containerization analysis reproducible down to the software level we're not reproducing anything hardware effects i can show this later but yeah if there's like a cpu difference between intel and amd or arm we don't control that but down to the software level it's reproducible
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: then this whole uh system is only 1.5 gigabyte in size and the reason is we can stream all the software we need on demand in here so when you actually click on a software it is streamed live to this endpoint you can also choose to download it but then we realized that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We look at brain imaging data and check if things worked or didn't work.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then also we wanted to support high performance computing systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So high performance computing systems, they don't often come with a desktop interface.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you need to work from the command line.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we build everything to integrate with these HPC systems so you can easily run NeuroDesk on there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Often you can't install things on there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we took care of making that possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you don't need any elevated privileges if you have Singularity or Optane already installed on your HPC.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we also support Jupyter and notebooks, computation notebooks in general, because we think this is a great way of documenting and analysis, experimenting, collaborating with other people and sharing results in the end.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we really build it into JupyterLab as well and provide with this very nice interface to people that they are used to, that I know how to work with.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then it's also very easy to contribute new software to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's all automated on GitHub.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have GitHub actions where people can propose a recipe for a software that gets automatically built, tested and integrated into the whole system and made available.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we have a system which is called CDMFS, the streaming of software that I mentioned.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's developed at CERN.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So CERN used CDMFS to stream software and instrument data across the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we use exactly the same system and also collaborate with the people who run these servers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have a primary server where we ingest all the software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we distribute it worldwide.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So wherever you are in the world, you should get a quick access to the software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's a client in there that localizes where you are and gives you the closest server.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And even if the server is down, it just goes to the next server.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it should be a quite reliant system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we're using this as a couple of years and have never had any issues with that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then for the end user, it just appears magically there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They just see the software there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And when they started, it just magically works.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's just on the first start, it's a little bit slower because it has to download certain things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then on the second start, it's cached locally and it behaves like it was installed locally.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the uptake in the community is pretty impressive and we saw really big growth over the last years.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have more than a thousand monthly users on our systems that come from over 60 countries.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So really worldwide adoption.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We see that more than 16,000 people downloaded our main software container that provides a lot of these things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's used in university courses for teaching.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's used in conference workshops because it's fantastic for
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: standardizing teaching material because you can't, you don't have the problem that students have different software requirements on their computers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They all log in into either a cloud-based system or to install our software container, and then they can run all the same analysis, which is fantastic.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we also have various collaboration models that we support with this because we realized that in some instances, it's nice to have a central compute instance where people all log in and they all work on the same data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is fantastic for open data sets.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is fantastic if people are actually all in the same institution and they all collaborate on an institutional server.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and that's really useful and used a lot also for teaching obviously that's a really great setup because teachers can then log into the other students notes and quickly have a look what's happening there if they if they struggle if they have a problem
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then we also have this federated model where every, let's say, researchers are collaborating from different institutions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They just install it on their infrastructure, on their computer, and they run analysis on their data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then they can, for example, aggregate high level results in a publication without sharing actual any confidential data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So let's say brain extraction or brain, let's say,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: cortical thickness measurements, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you could easily share those without actually exposing the patient data that's underlying this, and then that can be shared across different institutions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's a really cool model as well that we see often used with our project.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And with this, I claim that we made maintaining and installing scientific software fun again.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's now very easy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Basically, you install NeuroDesk on these different systems, and we make sure that the software runs on these systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So even very recently, we managed to get our containers running on an MRI scanner.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this works particularly well for the Siemens ecosystem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So Siemens has a software platform called Open Recon.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can actually build a software container
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: that can directly be integrated into a reconstruction running on the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that is really closing the loop.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So now you could acquire data, build a core model, and then deploy it on an MRI scanner where patients can directly be scanned and the results end up in the PACS system for people to look at.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's really great progress over the last months that we've made there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I want to quickly show the open data workflow in NeuroDesk.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is something that we always focus on a lot.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We want to make consuming and producing open data a lot easier.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we've built there over the last years is that we support a lot of tools and databases that make that possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I'll start with importing data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So usually if you produce open data, you would start from, for example, an MRI scanner or an EEG system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or you would download data from, for example, Open Neuro or the Open Science framework.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we have a tool in there that's called DataLad that can handle a lot of these cases where we can download data from these systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Also, XNet we support, which is a tool commonly used in the neuroimaging space to archive data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we, of course, support any cloud provider or any local connection.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So pretty much anything.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is not a complete list.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is just a couple of examples of what we support.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Once the data is in the system, we can process the data using pretty much any software out there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If the software is not yet there, it can easily be added.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We currently have more than 100 pieces of software in there that the community wanted.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we can organize the data and we can document our analysis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We highly work with the BITS standard for the brain imaging data structure, but also BITS has been extended to the EEG world.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we support this as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We support Jupyter, as I said, as a way of documenting this data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But you can use also your own script system, whatever you're used to, you can install it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we wanted to make it very easy to share data with the community.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we support Google Colab, for example.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you can write your analysis in Jupyter and then you can provide, for example, a Google Colab notebook with your paper where all the analysis run and we stream the software into Google Colab.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So with this, we can even run software that wouldn't be able to run in Google Colab.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, because you couldn't install it because Google Colab doesn't have enough disk space, for example, to install a certain piece of software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we can actually run the software in Google Colabs for our streaming service.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But also, we made sure that we can easily upload data back to Open Neuro, again, through Data Lab, or we can share data out to OSF, or that we can share our analysis quickly on GitHub.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then people can start again from this and can use our data that we produced or our derivatives that we produced, and then start the cycle again, and then really, yeah, enrich the open ecosystem out there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So people often ask, what is our sustainability model will be around in the next couple of years?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And of course, that's a very good question, because if you start adopting a framework like this, you invest time learning it and you want to be sure that it's around.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we try our best there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we, as I said, we have been funded
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: through an AITB platform grant in the past.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We're currently funded by the Mark and John Zuckerberg Foundation through Wellcome Trust.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we're applying for grants left and right to keep the system growing and developing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But of course, grant funding is very competitive.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And of course, grants always want to fund things that are new.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They don't want to fund things in maintenance mode.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that is definitely something that we anticipate.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's why we really want to build the community.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we already have 10 more than 10 active contributors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We have a lot of the infrastructure hosted through the community, through the Open Science Grid, the EGI Foundation, where we don't have basically cloud builds for us, which keeps our costs very low, which is good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Also, if we have helpers from the community, we can also lower our costs because we don't have to do certain work.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we provide NeuroDesk as a service as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this goes through a non-for-profit foundation, which is called the Queensland Cyber Infrastructure Foundation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what they do is they provide NeuroDesk at a certain cost for, for example, a conference, for a workshop or for university.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So let's say you don't want to use the open source software and do everything yourself.

text: So I want to quickly show you some results from this reproducibility aspect, because I'm always claiming that NeuroDesk is reproducible, but isn't.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And how reproducible is it?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is something that we looked at.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a PhD student in my group took that original paper that I showed earlier from Tristan Klattar, where they found these reproducibility issues with software.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we took that paper and tested, can we reproduce the non-reproducibility of software?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the analysis is the following.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We picked this part where we have data was scanned from an MRI scanner in anatomical space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What we have to do is we have to register it to the MRI space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this means we align it to a template space with a tool called FSL Flirt.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: then we take this data and we segment it so we segment subcortical areas and we measure for example the size of that so it's a very simple pipeline where you think that should be pretty easy to reproduce so what we did is we used a very similar setup than what klatar used in their paper where we have a local installation of fsl so fsl is the same
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then once we run on glibc versions 2.3.1, so on a Ubuntu 20.04, at the NeuroDesk, we chose a quite old version of Ubuntu with a quite old version of glibc.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But the cool thing is the glibc version is consistent, whereas here, the glibc version is 2.28, so something in the middle.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's on an Alma Linux 8.5.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then also what we varied is we varied the processors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here's an Intel i7, and here's an AMD EPYC processor.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: so let's see what happens so we of course we compare these different systems now let's see what happens so the first thing is image intensity differences so the first thing is we were able to replicate the problems from the paper so if you have a local installation with two different glibc versions then you get different results and this is really intensity so we
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We only focus on the intensity in the area where we will later do an analysis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it is actually intensity changes for brain, but just to show where the problems are.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we basically see that the intensity of a voxel is like up to one
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: one integer value different and this is small because when you think about the images are usually like 0 to 1024 so a change of one doesn't matter much but still it's a change and it shouldn't be there so
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the cool thing is when we run as a neural desk where we control glibc the glibc version this effect is not there there's nothing there and that's exactly how it should look like there shouldn't be a difference between this it's a fully deterministic analysis there shouldn't be any variance between that and that's cool
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So then when we look at the classification differences, so this is now when we segment this data, we see again in the local installation with different glibc versions, we see quite high disagreements between labels.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is now a dice score.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is between 0 and 1.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and a 0.16 die score is quite a lot when you think about it um so this means we actually disagree in certain areas quite a lot between segmentations and again that shouldn't be the case now in neurodesk you still see something then however note that the scale is an order of magnitude
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: scaled down so we had to scale it down to make anything visible there but we wanted to show it and why is that why is neurodesk here showing some non-reproducibility because i just claim that we are reproducible right and why are we suddenly not
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and we looked into this so we looked we traced the executions of this program and we found that as expected in the local installation the software diverges so we're doing different things on different computers with different glibc versions and that's why we're getting different results so that explains it it's great on neurodesk we're not diverging we're doing exactly the same thing on both computers
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this means on a software level, it's reproducible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But why is there still a different result?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the reason is that we use different processors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it was an Intel processor.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One was an AMD EPYC processor.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So different instruction sets, different floating point positions can still have an effect that we cannot control for, even if we do
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: everything the same we get still small differences they're tiny but they're still there so it's something to to note that 100 reproducibility will only be possible if you also control the hardware but then
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In the end, you have to have a trade off there, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: When is reproducibility enough and how much effort do you want to put into having reproducible results there?
